case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh and the District Magistrate Meerut v. the plaintiff

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 28th October, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 993 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 28th October, 1066 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 993 of 1960. N. Dikshit and 0. P. Rana, for the appellants.

facts.text: This appeal by special leave at the instance of the State of Uttar Pradesh and the District Magistrate Meerut briefly the defendants.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GoswAmi, J. This appeal by special leave at the instance of the State of Uttar Pradesh and the District Magistrate Meerut  briefly the defendants  is directed against.the judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 993 of 1960 whereby the High Court dismissed the same.

facts.text: The sole respondent hereinafter described as the plaintiff instituted suit No. 678 of 1956 on July 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts are briefly as follows The sole respondent  hereinafter described as the plaintiff  instituted suit No. 678 of 1956 on July 16, 1956, praying for a permanent injunction against the defendants restraining them from recovering certain amount and from threatening to evict him from the 3/8th portion of the premises in suit in his occupation situated in Wright Gunj, Ghaziabad.

facts.text: Plaintiff praying for permanent injunction against defendants from recovering certain amount and threatening to evict from 3/8th portion of premises in Wright Gunj, Ghaziabad.

anchor.surface_text: praying for a permanent injunction against the defendants restraining them from recovering certain amount and from threatening to evict him from the 3/8th portion of the premises in suit in his occupation situated in Wright Gunj, Ghaziabad.

facts.text: Plaintiff describes himself as a duly allotted tenant of the portion of the house on a monthly rental of Rs. 4/4/- for some time.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff describes himself as a duly allotted tenant of the portion of the house on a monthly rental of Rs. 4/4 for some time. He had offered the said rent, but neither the Government number the owner of the premises accepted the same.

facts.text: District Magistrate by a notice dated April 21, 1955, cancelled the allotment order under which the plaintiff was holding the 3/8th portion of the house No. 36.

anchor.surface_text: When subsequently the District Magistrate wanted to eject him from the house, the plaintiff, by some arrangement, became the direct tenant of the landlord. The District Magistrate by a numberice dated April 21, 1955, as stated therein, cancelled the allotment order under which the plaintiff was holding the 3/8th portion of the house No. 36 and numberified the plaintiff- that be shall be deemed to be in unauthorised occupation of the Government premises under section 3 of the U.P. Government Premises  Rent Recovery and Eviction  Act 1952,  briefly the Act .

facts.text: Plaintiff deemed to be in unauthorised occupation under section 3 of the U.P. Government Premises Rent Recovery and Eviction Act 1952.

anchor.surface_text: cancelled the allotment order under which the plaintiff was holding the 3/8th portion of the house No. 36 and numberified the plaintiff- that be shall be deemed to be in unauthorised occupation of the Government premises under section 3 of the U.P. Government Premises  Rent Recovery and Eviction  Act 1952,  briefly the Act .

facts.text: Notice sent to plaintiff by District Magistrate on October 14, 1955, to vacate within thirty days.

anchor.surface_text: Another numberice ,was also sent to the plaintiff by the District Magistrate on October 14, 1955, calling upon him to vacate the said premises within thirty days of service of the numberice failing which he would be liable to be forcibly evicted therefrom.

facts.text: Notice under section 12 of the Act on April 24, 1957, assessing Rs. 1522/10/9 as damages at Rs. 21/6/6 per month from December 15, 1949 to November 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: A numberice was also sent by the, District Magistrate to the plaintiff under section 12 of the Act on April 24, 1957, supersession of his earlier numberice of November 24, 1956, assessing this time Rs. 1522/10/9 as damages at the rate of Rs. 21/6/6 per month for the unauthorised occupation of the premises from December 15, 1949 to November 21, 1955, inclusive of numberice fee and interest to be realisable, as arrears of Land Revenue under the Act.

facts.text: Notice under section 80 CPC served on April 13, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: After serving a numberice under section 80 of the Civil Procedure Code on April 13, 1956, the present suit was instituted by the plaintiff in the Court of the Munsif, Ghazibad.

facts.text: Suit instituted in Court of Munsif, Ghaziabad.

anchor.surface_text: the present suit was instituted by the plaintiff in the Court of the Munsif, Ghazibad.

facts.text: Premises requisitioned under Defence of India Rules on July 26, 1946 and derequisitioned on November 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: according to them, the premises had been requisitioned under the Defence of- India Rules on July 26, 1946 and were derequisitioned on November 21, 1955.

facts.text: Plaintiff remained in possession from December 15, 1949 to November 21, 1955 without valid allotment order.

anchor.surface_text: During the above period of requisition the plaintiff remained in possession of the suit premises from December 15, 1949 to November 21, 1955 without any valid allotment order under the Act.

facts.text: Trial court decreed the suit allowing permanent injunction against proceeding under the Act for recovery.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decreed the suit allowing the relief of permanent injunction against the defendants from proceeding against the plaintiff under the Act for recovery of the amount as arrears of Land Revenue under the Act.

facts.text: Defendants' appeal to Second Civil Judge, Meerut dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants appeal to the Second Civil Judge, Meerut, was dismissed.

facts.text: Second Appeal to High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: That led to the Second Appeal to the High Court which met with the same fate.

facts.text: U.P. Government Premises Rent Recovery and Eviction Act, 1952 came into force on December 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel for the appellants points out that the P. Government Premises  Rent Recovery and Eviction  Act, 1952, came into force on December 19, 1952 and the claim of the defendants for companypensation involved in this suit is for a period between December 15, 1949, and November 21, 1955.

facts.text: Dispute between parties regarding factum of requisition of premises under Defence of India Rules, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: There was dispute between the parties in the High Court with regard to the factum of requisition of the premises under the Defence of India Rules., 1939.

facts.text: No notification containing order of requisition under Rule 75A produced.

anchor.surface_text: No numberification companytaining the order of requisition of the premises under Rule 75A had been produced before the High Court number before us, numberwithstanding opportunity offered by the Court here,

facts.text: Premises not requisitioned property and not Government premises within section 2(c) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the materials on record it is number possible to say that the premises in suit were requisitioned property and Government premises within the meaning of section 2 c  of the Act. Accordingly the Act does number apply

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed. The parties will bear their own companyts in this Court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 28th October, 1066 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 993 of 1960. N. Dikshit and 0. P. Rana, for the appellants.

This appeal by special leave at the instance of the State of Uttar Pradesh and the District Magistrate Meerut  briefly the defendants  is directed against.the judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 993 of 1960 whereby the High Court dismissed the same.
After serving a numberice under section 80 of the Civil Procedure Code on April 13, 1956, the present suit was instituted by the plaintiff in the Court of the Munsif, Ghazibad.

Before the companymencement of the Act, suit was the only remedy for recovering the arrears of rent. But the Act gives another remedy for recovering arrears of rent to the Government. There is neither a vested right number a vested liability. in any procedure. The tenant or a trespasser of the government premises has numbervested right in the suit procedure.

arguments.claim: Respondent entitled to support High Court decree on grounds raised by him and decided against/not considered by courts below, by analogy to Order 41 Rule 22 CPC

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by several decisions of this Court that the respondent can support the decree on grounds raised by him and decided against him by the courts below on the analogy of the provisions of order 41, rule 22, Civil Procedure Code.

holdings.text: The U.P. Government Premises Rent Recovery and Eviction Act, 1952 applies to recovery of arrears of rent under sections 4 and 6 even where the occupation or letting commenced prior to the Act, if arrears are payable and premises are government premises.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 provides that where an arrears of rent is payable by any person for occupation of government premises, the companypetent authority may, at any time after 30 days from the date on which rent accrued due, serve upon the persons liable a numberice of demand for the amount due.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arrears 'is payable' means outstanding liability not time-barred; procedural remedy replaces suit; no vested right in prior procedure.

holdings.text: The procedure under section 12 for recovery of damages applies even if unauthorised occupation commenced prior to the Act, provided the premises are government premises.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 provides for a similar procedure for recovering damages from an unauthorised occupier of the government premises, The words is in unauthorised occupation of any government premises in section 12 are important.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same considerations as for rent arrears apply; object of Act defeated otherwise; conditional on government premises status.

holdings.text: No notification containing the order of requisition under Rule 75A of the Defence of India Rules produced despite opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: No numberification companytaining the order of requisition of the premises under Rule 75A had been produced before the High Court number before us, numberwithstanding opportunity offered by the Court here,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence despite court opportunity prevents finding of valid requisition.

holdings.text: No valid order of requisition of the premises could be passed by the District Magistrate under Rule 81(2)(bb) of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the order of the so called requisition passed by the District Magistrate under rule 81  2   bb , it is sufficient to state that numbervalid order of requisition of the premises companyld be passed under the sub- rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-rule does not permit valid requisition of premises.

holdings.text: Power of requisition under Rule 75A is conferred on the Government; no delegation to District Magistrate under section 2(5) of the Defence of India Act shown.

anchor.surface_text: Besides the power of requisition under Rule 75A is companyferred upon the Government and there is number delegation of this power by the Government under section 2 5  of the Defence of India Act in this case in favour of the District Magistrate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of delegation; power vested in Government only.

holdings.text: Premises in suit were not requisitioned property and not Government premises within section 2(c) of the Act; accordingly the Act does not apply.

anchor.surface_text: On the materials on record it is number possible to say that the premises in suit were requisitioned property and Government premises within the meaning of section 2 c  of the Act. Accordingly the Act does number apply

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof of valid requisition on record; hence not government premises.

holdings.text: Respondent entitled to support decree on grounds raised by him but decided against or not considered by courts below, by analogy to Order 41 Rule 22 CPC, without mutilating the decree.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled by several decisions of this Court that the respondent can support the decree on grounds raised by him and decided against him by the companyrts below on the analogy of the provisions of order 41, rule 14-L447SC174 22, Civil Procedure Code. The respondent, therefore, is entitled to recanvass the point here to support the decree of the High Court on ground rejected by it or even number companysidered by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well settled Supreme Court precedent allows respondent to urge alternative grounds to support decree.
